div.head: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for SUDAN, SUAKIN, direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidan, Aden. Intermediate steamersdo not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yamboas required. and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: REPRESENTATIVE GOVERNMENT IN EGYPT.
div.p: Representative government is not a plant which is much encouraged in Egypt, where the oircomstanoea are such as not to favor either its inception or any benefits from iti existence. From time to time attempts hare been made to introduce forms of municipal government with more or less anooesucesses. We leave the choice of adverbs to our readers who may be biassed, one way or the other. Probably the next town of importance to ask for such a consummation asnature a corporation will be Port Said. The polyglot nature of the community in a place like this, each nationality with its tastes and distastes, might give birth to a municipality of such a hybrid origin that like the serpent’s egg it might be better to nip it in the bad, lest as its kind it grow dangerous. The rapid increase of Port Said, both as regards the number of its population and the value and extent of its property, and the attention which it is now attracting as a commercial centre, justify prophecies of still further progress for the town. It might therefore be of some utility did representative townsmen have some say in that which appertains to the regulation thereof. From time to time there has been evidence that the citizens are sufficiently interested in the welfare of the place to assist in public movements for the common weal. If this undoubted desire for improvement were organized and supervised into some body representative of the residents, possibly even without any executive authority, they might have some influence in assisting in the improvement of the town.

div.head: POWERS AND ABYSSINIA.
div.p: In a leading article on the subject of tbs formation by the French Minister of Foreign Affairs of an inter-Ministerial Commission on the Abyssinian question, the '‘Temps” insists that the question of the Dj bouti-Addis Abeba railway is far less complicated than it is generally supposed to be. The financial value of the line is a sufficiently definite figure. The financial status is not brilliant Now certain parties have come forward proposing to pay for the railway much more than it is worth. Consequently they must have had other than merely pecuniary objects. What were these objects asks the "Temps." It replies, “the possibility of isolating a great port in the Golf of Aden and the possibility of isolating Abyssinia.” To-day, continues the "Temps," the relations between France and England are so exceptionally cordial that there is no longer any idea in England of transforming the French into an English company, as was the case in 1902, when the French Parliament voted 25,000,000f. (£1,000,COO) to subsidize the French line, but there is much talk of its internationalization. The “Tempe” is convinoed that the English shareholders are not instigated by their Government to insist on the internationalization of the company. The shareholders hope that by the liquidation of the present company an international combination would take over shares at a price much higher than would be given by a French company, for the simple reason that the participating Governments would probably be disposed to give a fair sum for their share of influence. The interest of the British and French shareholders is the same, so that it is not surprising that there are in Prance partisans of inter- nationalization. The "Temps" points oat that if the Abyssinian question bas become apparently very complicated it is chiefly became French foreign policy aa to that country has been lacking in continuity.Djibouti is of the highest importance to France, and it should be norm- ally the outlet for Abyssinia The only way to make it such is to keep the railway from Abyssinia to the sea in French bands. When ones this principle has bean clearly affirmed tbs attitude to be adopted towards the interested Powers, Menelik and the company, will b* much simplified. The claim for internationalization will be seen to be less serious than may have been imagined.

div.head: Local and General
div.p: Cairo Bourse.
The Khedivial Bourse, Cairo, will be open between 10 a.m. and noon on and after to day and until farther notice.
Popular University.
Dr. Calzolari gives his lecture on “Evolu- zione, Educazione e Religione at the Popular University this evening at 9.15 o’clock.
Damletta Customs.
Ahmed Bey El-Abani, inspector in the Customs Administration, has been appointed sob director of the Damietta custom house.
New Hospitals.
The Public Health Department has decided to construct a hospital for ophthalmia at Tantah and another for contagions diseases at Benha.
Hard Labour for Life.
The Zagszg Native Criminal Court has sentenced the authors of the attempt made on the life of the moawin of Belbeis Markaz, at Izbet El Nakhas, to imprisonment for life with hard labour.
Erratum.

In a paragraph about the suicide of a Greek boy in Saturday’s issue, we inadvertently stated that the unhappy youth belonged to the Averoff School. This is not so, as the boy went to a private school.
Army Inspection.

The 4th Battalion Worcestershire Regiment, which recently arrived in Egypt, was inspected at Mustapha Pacha on Saturday by Major- General Bullock, C.B., G.O C. in Egypt, who returned to Cairo this morning.
105 Dwellings Destroyed.

No less than 105 dwellings were destroyed by a fire which broke out on Friday at Nahiet el Kei ■. Beni Mazar Markaz The flames were fanned by a high wind, and it was with the utmost difficulty that the conflagration was finally extinguished.
San Stefano Casino.

The opening ball of the season at San Stefano Casino on Saturday last was a great success, as was only to be expected. The restaurant, previous to the dance, was crowded with diners, and the ball room presented a very animated scene until an advanced boor, Alexandria and Ramleh society being largely represented.
Boat Capsized.

A boat bound tor Deyront and Bein Mazar capsized on Saturday near Rod el Farag. Five natives were thrown into the water and were in imminent risk of drowning when M. Alphonso Keskiary, of the tramway excursion steamers service, immediately put out in a launch, and after rescuing the men in the water took the boat in tow and brought her ashore.
Bank of Egypt

An agency of the Bank of Egypt was opened at Esneh on the 15th inst. in the presence of the mamour, omdehs, and merchants of the town, as well as the agents of the Bank at Assouan and Beni Souef. Owing to the absence of the general manager, Lozzatto Pacha, the bank was opened by the legal adviser, Girgis Eff. Melikeb, who in a short speech explained the objects of the bank.
Shepheard's Hotel.

An entirely new story is to be added to Shepheard’s Hotel over the whole of the build- ing. A hundred new bedrooms will be comprised in this story, while the grill room and dining- I room are to be considerably enlarged. The fact that large numbers of tourists had to be sent away from the hotel last season explains and justifies the decision of the proprietors. Mr. C. Baehler is leaving Alexandria for Europe by the N. D. L. steamer on Wednesday and will return to Cairo in July.
Victoria College.

As only a limited number of invitations have been issued for the ceremony of the lay- ing of the foundation-stone of the new Victoria College by Lord Cromer next Thursday, all friends and those interested in the College are invited to apply for cards of admission to the reserved enclosure to the British Consulate, the headmaster of the College, or to the hon.- secretary, Mr. A. S. Preston, 6, Ramleh-boulevard.
Averoff Ciris' School.

On Saturday afternoon the annual gymnastic competition of the Greek girls at the Averoff School at Alexandria was held in the courtyard of the Orthodox Cathedral Evangelismos. Among the visitors present were his Beatitude Monsignor Photius I, Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Alexandria, Lybia, Pentapolis, Ethiopia, and All Egypt, Mr. Scotidis, Hellenic Consul-General, Messrs. B. Sivitanidis and Michel Sinadino, Vice-Presidents of the community, and a very representative assemblage of the community at Alexandria. The girls performed a number of most interesting gymnastic marceivres and exercises and displayed great dexterity in their movements. About four hundred girls were pre- sent and the spectacle was a most interesting one.

div.head: THE PRINCES’ CASE.
div.p: This morning’s hearing of the Princes' case was taken op by the conclusions of the Ministre Public, whose arguments were in nearly every respect the same as those employed by the Contentieux de l'Etat at the previous hearing of the case.

div.head: A RAJAH’S PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Jerusalem, Friday.

Early yesterday morning the S.S. Coromandel arrived at Jaffa, having on board H. H. Sahib Mohamed Sidick Khan Bahadur, Rajah of Nanpara, K.C I E., accompanied by the members of his household, which includes four wives, and a large relinue of servants and attendants, numbering altogether 65 persons, with the object of visiting the Holy City or "Beitnl- Makdes.” The Rajah and his suite could not land, as the steamer had to undergo 24 hours’ observation, which expired today, and to- morrow afternoon his Highness and party are expected to arrive here by a special train. The Coromandel is especially chartered by the Rajah for the voyage.

div.head: IRRIGATION DEPARTMENT.
div.p: Mr. T. H. Clowes, Inspector of Irrigation in Upper Egypt, has resigned his position for reasons of health, and has been granted two months’ leave dating from the 1st prox. Mr. Langley, Inspector of the 1st Circle of Irrigation, will probably succeed Mr. Clowes.

Shares joui’sances” : Gross 125.333f, net 117.549f. Founders’ shares : Gross 71.173f, net 66.629f. M. André Lebon and M*. GeorgeB Devin were appointed members cf the Council of Administration.

div.head: PORT SAID TO OSTEND BY CYCLE.
div.p: Lieutenant G- M. Routh, an officer in the Royal Artillery, arrived at Dover last week from Ostend. having made a remarkable jour- ney from Port Said on a bicycle. His eye’o- meter indicated 6,500 miles. The officer’s luggage, which was strapped to the machine, and weighed about one and a half hundred- weight, included a tent with a collapsible pole. Lieutenant Routh carried a specially construct- ed water-bottle.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: (From our Correspondent )
Suez, Sunday.

Commander Harold Christian, cf H.M.S. Perseus, and Captain B. Eustace, of H.M S. Fox, accompanied by Mr. V. Hughes-Laferla, British Pro-Consul at Suez, paid official visits to Ibrahim Halim Bey, Governor of Suez, on Monday and Saturday last, respectively. H.M.S. Persons is still anchored in the Suez roads, and H.M.S. Fox, after having taken banker coal, has moored in the North Basin of Port Ibrahim.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries S S. Niger, from Mar- seiles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday, and is due here tomorrow morning.

div.head: SANA REOCCUPIED.
div.p: FAIZI PACHA’S REVERSES.
SULTAN DETERMINED.
DISSATISFACTION OF TROOPS.
(From our Correspondent).
Port Said, Saturday.

A report has reached here that the rebels have reoccupied Sans. Faizi Pacha's reverses have caused a large increase in the concentration of forces to await reinforcements, transport, and commissariat. The report of the contemplated withdrawal of the Turkish troops from the Yemen is on- bonded. The Sultan is determined to main- tain his position in Southern Arabia. The troops on board the last Turkish trans- port are said to be dissatisfied. It was with difficulty that they were induced to land at Hodeidab.

div.head: TURKEY AND THE SAHARA.
div.p: A telegram from Tripoli of the 14th inst. states :— A Turkish expeditionary corps of 403 men and officers will be sent to occupy Janet, near the Oasis of Tripolitan Ghat The expedition is awaiting £4,000 for the expenses of the expedition. This telegram confirms one of come days ago from Tunis of Turkish activity at Ghat and Gadames. France is obliged to be on the qui-vive in her Tunisian protectorate.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
div.p: THE KASSALA. RAILWAY LINK
(From our Correspondent.)
Suakin, May 16.

The British steamer Turkestan is expected to arrive here from England in a few days. She brings out a special consignment of about 62 000 sleepers for the new Kassala line, the construction of which will be commenced about October next. The survey of this line has already been completed. It will branch off from Thamiam station, on the Suakin-Atbara line.

El Kaimakam Midwinter Bey, R.E., Assis- tant Director, Sudan Rail Nays, arrived here by special train on the 11th inst. on inspection duty. He left yesterday for Port Sudan accompanied by Bimbashi NewCombe, R.E., Agent, Sudan Railways, Suakin. The long-expected gratuity for officers and locomotive drivers who took part in the laying of the Suakin-Atbira line arrived this week, each receiving two months’ extra pay. Others have been recommended for this gratuity, but it has not yet been approved by the Ministry of Finance.

div.head: THE SCENERY OF AKABA.
div.p: The late Sir Richard Barton was not enthusiastic over the beauties of the Gulf of Akaba. Cruising up this arm of the Red Sea in 1878 he was struck by "the sterile horrors of the hideous Sinaitic shore,” which at Rss Kusayr, the "cape of the short one," reached a climax. The mountains, he writes, became huge rubbish heaps, each striving with its neighbour for the prize of repulsive ugliness, while the valleys were mere dost shunts, which shot their rubbish, stones, gravel, and sand, in a solid flow like a discharge of lava. But he found much to interest him on Pharaoh’s island. The existing fort, then, as now, garrisoned by Egyptian troops, must have been built, he thought, by Europeans, when the Crusaders held Akaba ; but there were traces of an older Roman fort, and, per- haps, r f still more ancient defence works built by the Pharaohs. The land fort at Akaba was held, when Barton arrived, by half a dozenTurkish gunners and a few Bashi Bazuks, all of whom were suffering more or less from ennui and the effects of the climate, the hot summer being almost insupportable.

Burton, though the main object of his journey was to discover gold mines in Midian, discusses at some length the long-vexed ques- tion as to the exact locality of Mount Sinai. On this point, however, it may be safer to follow Professor Sayce, who is of opinion that it must be sought for among the ranges of Mount Seir and in the neighborhood of Kadesh-Barnea, which lies to the north or north east of Akaba. The learned professor identifies the Yam Suf, the "sea of weeds” — the Red Sea of the authorised version—with the Gulf of Akaba ; and both he and Barton agree in scouting the old idea that the Mount Sinai of the Old Testament was in the Sinaitic peninsula. Of the surveys made of the gulf by our own Admiralty, and, a few years ago ,by the Austrian naval authorities, it would take too long to speak ; nor is it possible to do justice here to the work of the Palestine survey. It may be noted, however, that Captain Kitchener, RE, whose name was not quite so well known in those days aB it is now, wrote : "I don’t think I have ever done such bard work as np the Wadi Arabah from Akabah to the Red Sea.”

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Saturday’s plague bulletin recorded a case at Deshua, a case and a recovery at Samalont, five oases (two fatal) and a death at Ghirgeh.

div.head: TABAH SETTLEMENT.
div.p: SIR EDWARD GREY'S ANNOUNCEMENT

In the House of Commons last Monday, Mr. Lupton asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs how far Tabah was from the frontier claimed by Egypt and from the Suez Canal ; had the frontier claimed by Egypt ever been definitely marked out on the ground ; were the Turkish troops two months at Tabah before the Egyptian Government heard of the circumstacce ; were the Egyptian troops now in occupation of an island near Tabah which was claimed by the Turks as theirs ; and, considering that Tabah was 130 miles from Suez, whether he would continue negotiations for the delimitation of the frontier without insisting on the previous evacuation of Tabah.

Sir E. Grey : Instead of answering the question on the paper, perhaps the House will allow me to make a statement. (Cheers. Just before I came into the House I received information that a satisfactory Note had been received from the Porte. (Cheers.) The Turkish Government has informed Sir Nicholas O'Con- or that Tab ah and all other places in that neighborhood recently occupied by Turkish troops have been evacuated, and since then a Note has been received that the Porte does not question the telegram of April 8, 1892. A joint commission will be appointed to make a topographical survey and a map, with a view to fixing boundaries, so as to secure the maintenance of the states quo on the basis of the telegram above mentioned. The boundary will ran from Rafah in a south-easterly direction to a point not less than three miles from Akaba. His Majesty’s Government have accepted this reply to the Note they sent, and it gives us every reason to hope that a completely satisfactory settlement of details will be arrived at. (Cheers.)

Mr. Dillon asked when full papers would be presented. Sir E. Grey : I will do everything I can to meet the wishes of the hon. member. I should like to consider the question of presenting papers, and I should be glad if he will give me notice of his question. At a later stage, Sir E. Grey gave the following answer to Mr. Lupton’s question : , Tabah is three or four miles from the line claimed by Egypt. Tabah to Suez is about 140 miles. No delimitation of the frontier on the ground has taken place. It is not certain how long Turkish troops had been at Tabah before they were discovered by the Egyptian autho- rities ; but they had not been there more than two months. The island of Faraon is now occ- upied by Egyptian troops.and their retirement was requested by the Turkish Commandant at Akaba. The evacuation of Tabah pending a settlement was demanded by his Majesty’s Government in the Note presented to the Porte ten days ago; but I hope to be able to- morrow to make a statement respecting the negotiations, and wold ask to defer any farther observations till then.

In the House ofLords Lord Fi'zmaurice., in reply to a question by the Earl of Halsbury, mule a statement couched in terms similar to those employed by Sir E Grey in the House of Commons. His lordship added: I have already informed the House that a promise had boon received that the pillars at Rafah w'll be restored. It will thus be seen that all the demands of his Majesty’s Government have been fully root.” (Cheers.)
The Egyptian members of the Boundary Commission will probably leave on Wednesday. The arrangements for their transport and pro- visioning to Tor are in the hands of Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son.

div.head: RESTORING THE BOUNDARY-ERAARS.
div.p: A TURKISH RUSE.
Jerusalem, Friday.

The Governor of Jerusalem recently instruc- ted the Kaimakams of the districts of Gaia and Beersheba to repair to Rafah and take measures for the recovery of the missing boundary pillars with a view to having them restored to their proper place. They have now reported to his Excellency that they could not find any trace of thorn, and that conse- quently they aTe led to believe that the beacons in question mast have been broken to pieces and buried in the sand.

The result having been communicated to the Porte, orders were again received insisting on the pillars being restored without delay, and before the arrival of the Mixed Com- mission appointed for the delimitation of the frontier. Thereupon, the Governor, who was informed in the meantime that a number of pillars from old rains were to be found lying about in the vicinity, ordered that two columns of the size of the missing ones be transported and put up instead immediately, which arrangement has, I understand, been carried out to day in the presence of the British consular agent at Gaza; who proceeded to the locality to see that the newly-procured pillars were placed on the very same spot where the former ones stood.
It has also been arranged that the Turkish force at Rafah should retire some distance north of the pillars.

div.head: THE EVACUATION
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Suez, Sunday

H.H.S. Nour el Bahr returned to Suez yesterday afternoon from Akaba. H.M.S. Diana is expected at Suez any moment now from Faraon Island. The Turkish troops evacuated Tabah early last Sunday morning, in presence of H.M.S. Diana and the Nour el Bahr.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H H. the Khedive has conferred the follow- ing decorations on the undermentioned officials of the Cairo Police School : Medjidieh (3rd Class), Bimbashi Khalil Ed. Hamdj, head- master, and Ahmed Eff. Lutfy; Medjidieh (4th Class), Mohamed Eff. Osman ; and the grade of Sanieh on Ismail Bey Rafat
M. Ladislas Gyorgyey, Austro-Hungarian Consul at Berlin, has been appointed Consul at Alexandria, vice Chevalier Puscariu, who has been transferred to Kieff. M. Gyorgyey is expected hereon June 1

A memorial service is to be held in Claver- ing Church, Shropshire, on the occasion of the dedication of a moral tablet to the memory of the late Major General Sir William Gatacre, • on Saturday, the 26th inst.

Sir Edward Clarke, who is now fully restored to health, h?s arrived in London from Egypt. Interviewed with reference to tho dispute that has arisen respecting his attitude on fiscal reform, he stated that his opinions had undergone no charge, and were the same as expressed in his speech before his illness. He had no intention of retiring from Parliament, and, indeed, did not know that the situation in London was regarded with each seriousness.
Lieut.-Col. J. H. Gideon, Lieut. R. Haworth, 2nd-Lient. H. W. M. Yates, 1st Lancashire Fusiliers, and Rev. W. S. Jaffray, C. F., have been granted leave of absence.
Professors H. R Brian and H. W. Berry, of the Military School of Cairo, have obtained two months’ leave of absence.
Drs. Thomas Bogie Hamilton and Armanak Nichan have been authorised to practise in Egypt.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Ex- change Hotel, Port Said, are Mr. Sibbald and family, Mr. H. Clay, Mr. R. Sinclair, Capt Middleton, Dr. Milton and family, Mr. H. div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: The following is the agenda of the meeting of the Municipal Commission to be held on Wednesday next: —
1.Communications diverses.
2.Projet de Mr. Joseph pour la construction d’une jetée promenade an Port Eat
3.Proposition tendant á la nomination d’an chauffeur mécanicien pour le service de la pompe automobile et pour l’inspeotion des automobiles.
4.Demandes de crédits :
1. £120 á titre supplémentaire pour le homage des terrains des quais.
2. £200 pour certaines reparations k effec- tuer á des parties de chaussées des quais.
3. £1450 pour la construction du collec- teur Ibrahim.
4 £240 pour schat de chevaux hongrois pour le service des Pompiers.
5.£108 pour frais extra judiciaires. Les crédits cidessus seront imputés sur le budget extraordinaire.
6.£60 pour le loyer des bureaux sanitai- res (k imputer sur la reserve da budget ordi- naire.
7.£17000 pour construction de la route de la corniche.
5. Avis des Comités des Travaux Publics au sujet da sous-loissement des quais et éva- luation de certaines parcelles modifiées.
6. Avis des Comités d'hygiène et des Tra- vaux Publics an sujet du destructeur d'im- mondices.
7. Nomination de membres suppleants à la Delegation et do Conseil du Tanzim.
8. Question relative à l’introduction de la viande congelée en Ville.
9. Proposition tendant à donner à une rue la denomination “Stier”.
10. Question de principe an sujet de l’esti- mation des ziadets du Tanzim.
11. Excédents et empries divers.

Thomas Brown, Bandmaster.
MESSAGERIES MARITIMES
EXERCICE 1905

Les recettes d'exploitation réaliséss en 1905 par les Messageries Maritimes ont atteint le chiffre le plus élevé constaté dans les comptes de la Compagnie: 81,337.024 frs. pour 953,202 lieues marines parcourues avec 200,163 passa- gers transportés.

Malgré cette brillante situation, les corn missaires des comptes conseillent de conso- lider le présent par le renforcement des réser- ves, par l'extinction des charger financières et de préparer l'avenir par la construction de navires neufs de grand tonnage, et cela en raison de la crise ouvrière, de la concurrence étrangère et des avantages stipulés par la nou- velle loi sur la marine marchande. Aussi ap- prouvent-ils pleinement le principe d’une aug- mentation éventuelle du capital social de la Compagnie.
Les-produitsdes lignes ont atteint 61,812,345 frs. en augmentation de 11,647,165 frs. Les primes à la navigation ont rapporté 3 935 170 fr. soit près de 2 millions en plus qu'en 1904

Il va de soi que les dépenses ont augmenté par suite de cet accroissement de trafic : 17,744,908 fr. de charbon contre 15,882,004 en 1904, 4,784.096 frs. de droits de transit du Canal de Suez contre 3,826,955 en 1904, et 5,396,644 fr. de droits de ports et frais de route contre 4,231,797 en 1904.

Enfiu, en raison des charges financières spé- ciales, les intérêts sur capitaux qui figuraient en recettes pour 221,161fr. dans les comptes de 1904, sont portés en dépenses pour 207,842 fr. dans ceux de 1905.

L'exoédent des recettes sur les dépenses qui était de 7,997,993 fr. l'année dernière, attei- gnaitau 30 novembre dernier 11,169,05m fr., dégageant ainsi une plus-value de 3,171,065 fr. en laveur du présent exercise. Déduction faite des intérêts des obligations, il reste donc une somme disponible de 8,709,813.

Sur ce total, il sera prélevé d’abord 1 million en faveur du fonds d’assurance et 5,288,000 fr. destinés aux amortissements du matériel naval. Ces répartitions opérées, ainsi que celles ayant trait à l’amortissement des frais d’émission, au compte supplémentaire do prix des obligations et à la caisse de prévoyance des employés, il reste une somme suffisante pour donner á tou- tes les actions un dividende de 12. fr. 50. soit 5% du capital nominal et le solde à reporter est de 45,285

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: {Aujourd'hui à midi et demie)
Marché très calme : l'apathie des derniers jours de la semaine passée semble continuer.
A l'ouverture quelques petites valeurs ont été échangées; les Estates spécialement étaient très demandés à 1 11/16. Ils sont tombés à 12 1/32 en clôtare.
Les grosses valeurs restent stationnaires ou subissent de petites dépréciations.
L'Agricole perd 1/16 à 9 13/16, la National Bank également 1/16 à 26 1/8.
La Delta Light recule de 1/16 à 12 1/16, les Urbaines de 1/16 k 6 3/16.
Par contre, la Béhéra avance de 1/4 à 35 1/4, les Markets gagnent 6 pence à 26/6, la Salt and Soda 3 pences à 21.
L'obligation Crédit Foncier 1903 cote 270, la Banque d’Athènes cote 152 eu gain de 0,50 sur samedi
Les Nungovich remontent de 9/16 à 15 7/8.
La Delta Land perd 1/32 à 3 31/32.
L'Union Foncière clôture très demandée à 6 9/16, en hausse de 1/8. La tendance de cette valeur est excellente.

En somme, il n’y a paslieudes’effrayer, nous répétons ce que nous avons toujours dit : une reprise est obligatoire et nous pouvons nous attendre sous peu à un changement sinon très sensible tout au moins appréciable.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Samedi 19 Mai.

A Londres, Le Consolidé anglais est resté hier invarié à 89 3/4. L’Unifiée, la National Bank, la Daïra et la Delta Light ont également c’ôtoré à leurs prix de la veille. Sente l’Agri- cole a perdu 1/8 à 9 7/8.
A Paris, l'action Foncier Egyptien est de- meurés inchangée à 772. La Banque d’Athènes a réactionné de 1 frano à 150.
Ici, nous avons, eu ce matin, un marché géné ralement calme, mais tout de même plus animé, plus actif que celui d'hier, notamment dans le compartiment des Banques.

La National Bank a débuté à 26 1/32 pour avancer, sur quelques achats, à 26 1/4 et fini 26 7/32. L’Agricole a été également ferme et a clôturé à 9 7/8 Par contre, le Comptoir Finan- cier s’est alourdi à 5 3/4 l’action ancienne et 5 5/8 la nouvelle ; la part de fondateur est revenue à 38.
L’action Crédit Foncier a faibli b 775-776. La Béhéra est remontée k 35 et la Delta Light à 12 1/8.
L’agricole du Nil a été traitée k 265, ex- right
L’action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été demandée à 4 1/8-3/16, et l’Union Fon- cière à 6 7/16-1/2.
Les parts de fondateur Land Allotment ont reculé à 145.
L’action Brasserie des Pyramides a été ins- crite à 126, ex-coupon.
Le groupe des valeurs hôtelières a été lourd Les Nungovich ont été offerts à 15 5/16 l’ac- tion ancienne et 14 1/2 la nouvelle. Les Upper Egypt ont été cotés 41/4 ex-coupon.
Parmi les petites valeurs il y a eu de nom- breuses transactions en Delta Land, qui ont clôturé ferme à 4.
Les Hooker sont restés à 1 1/32. Les Estates ont clôturé à 1 11/16 ; les parts de fondateur ont baissé jusqu’à 9 7/8. Les Markets ont pro gressé and 26 sh. 3.

Les Salt and Soda sont restés à 21 sh. P, malgré une rumeur suivant laquelle la Société aurait obtenu la prolongation pour une période de 20 ans de son contrat avec le gouvernement concernant l’exploitation des salines de l’Etat
Les Sucreries ont passé de 14 à 16 franos.

Un journal du Caire a annoncé hier que ‘l'Association des courtiers a refusé d’ad- mettre à la cote de la Bourse Khédiviale du Caire les titres de la Gharbieh Land, des Excelsior Hotels et de l'Express Nile Steamers." Ainsi présentée, l’information est inexacte et passablement tendancieuse.
Relativement à la Gharbieh Land, l’assemblée extraordinaire de l'Association a simplement réservé sa décision jusqu’au résultat du pre- mier exercice, en attendant un complément de rapport.

Pour ce qui est de l'Excelsior Hotels et de la Nile Express Steamers, l'allégation du journal en question ost absolument erronée. L’assemblée n'a pris et ne pouvait prendre aucune décision pour la bonne raison que le Comité n’a pas encore présenté son rapport concernant ces deux Sociétés.
Le Comité de la Corporation des agents de change a décidé de fixer provisoirement les heures de séance de la Boarse Khédiviale du Caire de 10 h. à midi.
Ce nouvel horaire entrera en vigueur à par- tir de lundi prochain 21 Mai.
Il n'est pas impossible que les actionnaires de l’Anglo Belgian aient l’heur d’être fixés sur la valeur tout au moins nominale de leur titre.
On annonce, en effet, de Londres que la Compagnie a fait les démarches nécessaires dans la vue d’obtenir la cote au Stock Ex- change pour 70,000 actions entièrement ou partiellement libérées.

On sait que le capital nominal de la Socié té est de £ 1,000,000, divisé en 200,000 ac- tions de £ 5 chacine. Or, 100,000 actions avaient été offertes en souscription, dont 70,000 avaient été “garanties", d’après le prospectus, en d’autres termes placées avant l’émission publique.
Seraitce à dire que l’admission à la cote est demandée pour ces 70.000 actions, qui deviendraient seules négociables.
La 28èms assemblée générale ordinairo de l’Alexandria Water Co. aura lieu au siège social à Alexandrie le lundi 11 Juin prochain, à 4 heures et demie, p.m.
A l’ordre du jour: rapport da conseil, pré- sentation des comptes et bilan de l’exercice écoulé, fixation du dividende, etc.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The Asia Minor S.S. Co., Ltd., having acquired the goodwill and flag of the Bell’s Asia Minor S. S. Co., and their four steamers, the "BEAR”, "MILO”, -'ESPERANZA” and "BRAVO,”hereby give notice that they assume responsibility for ail expenses that shall be incurred on behalf of the four steamers above mentioned as from the respective dates of taking over each steamer, that is, as regards the "BEAR" and “MILO,” as on and from the afternoon of Friday, 4th May, 1906, and as regards the "ESPERANZA” and "BRAVO," ss on and from the afternoons of Thursday, lOth and Tuesday, 15th May, 1906, respectively.

All claims in respect of expenses incurred on behalf of any of the said steamers, prior to the said respective dates, are to be addressed to the Liverpool Head Office, or to the Alex- andria Agency of the old Company, The Bell’s Asia Minor S. S. Co., Ltd., in accordance with the notice advertised in the “Egyptian Gazette” of the 5th May, 1906.
For information relating to the business of the new Company apply to R- J. Moss and Company, Alexandrie, temporary.managers of the A. M. S.S. Co., Ltd. 27938-3*-3

div.head: Tofay's General
div.p: Great Britain and Russia
Negotiations for Understanding Advanced
Fleet to Visit Kronstadt
London. May 19.

The "Standard" is informed that the ne- gotiations for an Anglo Russian understanding, relating chiefly to Turkey, Persia, Afghanistan, and Tibet, have reached an advanced stage and will be completed when the new Russian Constitution is in working order. Russia does not seek to establish a port in the Persian Qulf. The north and south of Persia will be under the Russian and British spheres of influence respectively, separated by the Salt Desert.

The railway question is the chief difficulty and will possibly be settled by an agreement with reference to the Bagdad railway. The principle of the agreement in the Near East is the preservation of Turkey on the basis of the status quo. The position of Afghanistan and Tibet is unchanged. (Btmisr)
London, May 19.
The "Daily Telegraph” states that the Channel Fleet visits Kronstadt at the end of July.

div.head: Japan and Russia
div.p: RUMOURED DIPLOMATIC TENSION.
Tekio, May 20.

It is rumoured that diplomatic tension, exists between Japan and Russia. The latter is determined to ignore the Japanese protectorate over Korea, claiming that the Portsmouth Treaty recognised its independence. Great Britain and Germany are supporting Japan.
(Reuttr)

div.head: PEACE CONFERENCE.
div.p: London, May 20.
It is practically certain that the Peace Con- ference will not meet before May, 1907. (R.)

div.head: The Chinese Customs
div.p: GREAT BRITAIN’S PROTEST.
London, May 19.
The ‘Times’’ learns from Peking that the Japanese Legation has been instructed to sup- port Great Britain, and is asking for explana- tions in connection with the Customs edict.
(Reuter)
Peking, May 19.

All the foreign Ministers have announced their support of Great Britain’s protest against the Customs edict. The British Charge d’Af- faires has addressed a second Note to the Chinese Government. (Reuter)

div.head: Amnesty In Russia
div.p: St.Petersburg, May 19.
The amnesty wi'l be promulgated on the 27th May, the anniversary of the Tsar’s coronation. (Havas)

div.head: Opening of Simplon Tunnel
div.p: Brigue. May 19.
King Victor Emmanuel and M. Forrer, Pre- sident of the Helvetian Confederation, have opened the Simplon Tunnel. They drank toasts to Italo Swiss friendship. (Havas)
Rome, May 20.
King Victor Emmannuel has formally opened the Simplon Tunnel. (Reuter)

div.head: The Pope Ill
div.p: Rome, May 19.
The Pope is laid np in bed with gout. (R.)

div.head: FRENCH ELECTIONS.
div.p: Paris,May 20.

The second ballots give the victory to the Radicals and Socialists.Messars, Magnand,Buissot, Viviani, and Draint have been elete, while Messrs. Marchand, Déroulède and Driant have been defeated. (Hacas)

div.head: BOMB EXPLOSION IN FRANCE.
div.p: Poitiers, May 20.
A bomb exploded at Saint Chartres. Seven people were seriously injured. (Havas)

div.head: Natal Rebellion
div.p: Rearguard Action.
Cheifs Anxious To Surrednder
Burban, May 19
Two columns have effected a junction at Catewayo's grave. A rearguard action with Abmbaata has been fought in which twelve rebels were killed. Lieutenant Wilkins and a trooper were wounded. (Reuter)
Durban, May 20.

A Zulu rebel messenger informed a British officer that Sigananda and other important chiefs were anxious to surrender, being much impressed by the military operation. Native women who have surrendered say that the Zulu plans have been upset by the energy shown by the British. (Reuter)

div.head: “C.-B.” AND FEMALE SUFFRAGISTS.
div.p: London, May 19.
Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman received a deputation of female suffragists : he expressed sympathy with them, and urged them to have patience till the Government was more united on the question. (Reuter)

div.head: BURGOMASTERS LEAVE LONDON.
div.p: London, May 20.
The Burgomasters have left for home. (R)

div.head: AMERICAN RAILWAY RATES BILL.
div.p: Washington, May 19.
The Senate has passed the Railway Rates Bill, with amendments. (Reuter)

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: London, May 19.
Cricket. Kent v. Yorkshire : Yorkshire won by 119 runs. Hampshire v. Surrey : Surrey won by ten wickets. Oxford University v. Lancashire : Lancashire won by 141 runs. (R.)

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON PESTS.
div.p: The latest issue of the Bulletin of the Im- perial Institute contains an article on insects which attack cotton in Egypt. The account of these insects principally based on a report prepared by Mr.G.C. Dudgeon, Superintendent of Agriculture in British West Africa Colonies and Protectorates, in connection with a visit which he has paid recently to the cotton- growing districts of Egypt with the object o{ studying the cultivation of cotton in this j country. A colleotion of specimens illustrating the article is on view at the Imperial Institute.

Although for many years these enemies of the cotton plant have been prevalent in Egypt, the farmers have been very slow in recognizing them as the cause of injury to the crops, hot have attributed their effects to other causes, such as unfavourable tempera- ture or an insufficient supply of water. Even now the most destructive insect pest in Egypt, the Egyptian boll worm, has not had much attention paid to it, although it has reduced the yield of many plantations by as much as 75 per cent.

div.head: THE MOSLEM DOCTRINE OF GOD.
div.p: This “essay on the character and attributes of Allah according to the Koran and orthodox tradition’’ is an attempt to discriminate be- tween the monotheism of the Christian and the monotheism of the Mussulman, and its author. Dr. Zwemer, has a right to be beard, seeing that for the last fourteen years he "has been not only an earnest missionary to the Arabic-speaking Moslems of Bahrein, but an ardent student of all the literatuie of Islam." The study is painstaking and thoughtful, and —which is perhaps even more important—is condensed into a hundred and twenty pages. Dr. Zwemer finds his authorities for the eight chapters in which he analyses the Moha- medan doctrine of God in all its bearings, not only in the Koran, but in the "Hadith," or the records of the authoritative sayings and doings of Mohsmed, and the collection of orthodox traditions known as “Mishcat-ul-Masabih," which exhibits the origin of the manners and customs, the civil, military, and religious policy of Mussulmans. Dr. Zwemer’s conclu- sions are stroDgly in favour of Christianity aa against its rival. He maintain s earnestly that the ' Koran denies the Divinity and the eternal Sonship of Christ." The chapter entitled ‘‘Predestination v. Fatalism” is an extremely able exposition. Dr. Zwemer’s book is deserving of close attention as a piece of earnest thinking and writing.
“The Moslem Doctrine of God.” By Samuel M. Zwemer (Oliphant, Anderson, and Ferrier.3s,6d.)

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of Islr pUj to all, to permit -within certain necessary limits— free discussion.
AN APPEAL.

To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette.” Dear Sir,—I feel yon will allow me to make an appeal in your columns for a subscription towards an old gentleman of 86, who is now in circumstances which would generally be called poor and needy. His name is Albert Edelman, a British subject and a Doctor of Medicine, who took his diploma at Durpart, Russia. His history is a record of a busy life and extraordinary adventures. When the doctor had made a sufficient fortune, he settled down comfortably at Galveston, Texas, North America. A tidal wave in the year 1899 carried away everything he had. With extraordinary pluck and endurance he found his way through London to Paris, Palestine (where he obtained an apppointment which turned oat worthless), Alexandria, and Cairo, where he obtained a licence dated the 2nd of October, 1901, to practise his profession in Egypt, when he fell ill and was laid op in hospital for six weeks with a deep-seated abscess in bis leg. Barely recovered from that shook he proceeded to Australia ; the Grecia and Bulwer Lodges and Mr. Boyle contributing between them the cost of his passage.

His last misfortune was being ran over in Paris by a cab last autumn, when be broke his leg and sustained other injuries ; the hospital bill was paid by the Cabdrivers Association and a society subscribed to pay his passage to Egypt to recover his health. He arrived last December and since that date I have been in constant touch with him and have been struck with the veracity of all statements.

I have qualified the expression "poor and needy” in the beginning of this letter, because though this qualification may apply financially it does not apply, in the ordinarily accepted sense, to one who, in spite of his advanced years, has had the grit to travel around the world "poor and needy" and always managed to fall on his feet and that without importunate begging. He has found wherever he has been those who were anxious to relieve any- one in distress and it is only to this class I address this appeal.

In the very short summary I have given above of this eventful and useful life I have omitted many items which, though I believe to be foots, are too extraordinary to be accepted as each, without trespassing far more on year space than I should wish owing to the necessarily long explanations required.
The doctor has been living with me for the last two months and I have never found him oat in a misstatement, so I believe in him. If any of your readers care for farther details I will give them.

Messrs. Garofalo, Hayes, Hanauer, Clifton, Plunkett, Inglis, and R. H. Duke, besides your good self, have accepted to receive subscriptions from any anxious to exercise that great privilege illustrated by the parable of the good Samaritan.
Yours truly,
Brotherly love, Relief.and I hope Truth.

div.head: Army and Navy.
div.p: ( From the Correspondent.)
London, May 12.

Brigadier General G. M. Bullock, C.B., com- manding the British troops in Egypt, has been granted the temporary rank of major-general. This indicates that he will remain in the com- mand, although the forces there have been largely increased.

With the early arrival of the 6th Inniskilling Dragrons and U Battery R.H.A., the troops in Egypt will number a little over 6,000 of all arms. It is intended to keep them at this strength for some time to come. This is a course that has always been advocated in these notes,

The appointment of Brevet-Colonel G. J. Cuthbert from the half pay list to the post of Assistant Adjutant General of the Staff in Egypt, is generally recogoised as a happy ter- mination to a rather nasty affair, which bid fair to mar his fine military career through the impulsiveness of his subalterns in the Soots Guards "ragging” affair. It would have been too bad bad the Service lost such a splendid officer. Colonel Cuthbert has proved bis ability in many ways, and his selection for his new berth was no doubt guided by the fact that he has had considerable experience in Egypt and the Sudan. He was frith the Soots Guards daring their tour of service at Suakin in 1884, when they had some sharp work with gallant "Fuzzy-Wuzzy” at Hasheen and Temai (medal with clasp, and Khedive’s star), and in the late South African War, he saw a lot of service with the Household troops in the advance to the relief of Kimberley ; the actions of Belmont, Euslin, Modder River, and Magersfontein; Poplar Grove and Driefontein; Johannesbnrg, Pretoria and Diamond Hill; j the minor affoirs in the Transvaal, action of Belfast and the advance to Komati Poort, and the harassing operations in Orange River Colony and Cape Colony (twice mentioned in despatches, brevet lieutenant colonelcy, Queen’s medal with six clasps, King’s medal with two clasps).
Lieutenant-Colonel R.C.C. Cox, Royal Innis- killing Fusiliers, the popular cbief of the 2nd Battalion at Cairo, has been promoted brevet- colonel from yesterday.

It may interest gunners in Egypt to learn that the Royal Field Artillery batteries at Aldershot have been recently doing excellent work with the new 18-pounder on the ranges, at Dartmoor, Okehampton. The fire results were good, bat a rather curious defect has jest been discovered in an unexpected quarter. The gunners in action are protected from rifle fire and shell splinters by steel shields. moented on the axletree and the trail. These shields, it appears, catch the son’s rays, even in partial cover, and betray at once the location of the gun. This is a serious defect in any country and more particularity in tropical countries, when sunshine predominates largely. Instruc- tions have been issued to observe this reflectins, with the view to having it remedied. From reports to hand the 18-pounder is np to every- thing claimed for it. The ammunition supply in section, however, is a problem not yet satisfactorily solved.

Last year some very caustic comments wen made on the very poor shooting of the Atlantic Fleet. The reproach has disappeared this year as the ships of that fl et have made particularly good practice at the targets. Bombardier Nicholl, behind a 9‘2-inch gun of the battle- ship Hindustan, hit the mark ten times in ten rounds, find in two minutes; Gunner M’Kenzie, of H.M S Ocean, fired seven rounds from a 6 inch gun in one minute, and scored seven hits, and Petty Officer Giles, of the King Edward VII., with a similar gun, made the world’s record of eleven hit in eleven rounds in one minute. Other ships, the Victorious and Dominion included, have done well.
